definition: to take great pains/to go to a lot of trouble
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
to cost/to spend/fee/wasteful/expenses
surname Fei
surname Zhou/Zhou Dynasty (1046-256 BC)
to make a circuit/to circle/circle/circumference/lap/cycle/complete/all/all over/thorough/to help financially
week/weekly/variant of 周[zhou1]
chapter/section/clause/movement (of symphony)/seal/badge/regulation/order
surname Zhang

sentences.english: Nocturnal insects such as moths wouldn't need such large goblets to be lured over.
sentences.chinese: 勾引飞蛾一类的食弥昆虫根本不需要如此大费周章。

sentences.english: In practice the transition might have been messy.
sentences.chinese: 但实践中，这种转变大费周章。

sentences.english: Is that person in the bed next to you worth the trouble?
sentences.chinese: 睡在你身边的人值得你去大费周章吗？

sentences.english: "But, Dupin, " I said, "why did you go to the trouble of replacing the letter?Why not just take it and leave?
sentences.chinese: 你为何大费周章去替换那信，为什么不直接拿走呢？

definition: to muster large forces/to get a great number of people involved (in carrying out some task)
to go to war (idiom)/to make a big fuss over sth
to rack one's brains (idiom); to take great pains to think sth through
to do more than is required (idiom); superfluous/gilding the lily
to rack one's brains for schemes (idiom)/to beat one's brains out
to plot actively (idiom)/scheming/calculating
with great fanfare
to take a lot of trouble (idiom); painstaking/at the cost of a lot of effort
to take a lot of trouble (over sb or sth)/may I trouble you (to do sth)
there is no need/why should
to spend (much) effort/to go through (a lot of) trouble
worthwhile (often in rhetorical questions, implying not worthwhile)/also written 犯得上
to spend effort/to take trouble/May I trouble you to...? (as part of polite request)/Please would you mind...?
troublesome/to take a lot of trouble to do sth
to do the job oneself
to fool people (idiom)/to pull the wool over people's eyes
